As an AI language model, I can provide information on how these policies have impacted education, but it's difficult to say definitively whether they have improved education or not. Education is a complex and multifaceted field, and there are many factors that contribute to students' success. Moreover, the policies listed above have had different effects on different groups of students, and their implementation has varied across different states and school districts.

That being said, there is evidence that some of these policies have had positive impacts on education. For example:

- The Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA) provided funding for schools serving low-income students, allowing them to better support student learning and development.

- Title IX increased access to education for girls and women and helped to address gender discrimination in schools.

- The Standards Movement and the implementation of standardized testing have helped to establish clearer expectations for students and provide schools with data to identify areas where students need further support.

- Inclusive education policies have helped to increase access to education for students with disabilities and create more diverse learning environments that benefit all students.

However, many of these policies have also been subject to criticism and debate. For example, standardized testing has been criticized for narrowing the curriculum, fostering a culture of teaching to the test, and contributing to student stress and disengagement. Some also argue that the focus on standards and accountability has led to a devaluation of soft skills, creativity, and critical thinking in education. The impact of these policies on students' learning and development, as well as on the equity and quality of education across different communities, remains an ongoing area of research and discussion in the field of education.
